data.title: Warriors send David Lee to Celtics for Gerald Wallace
data.meta_description: Warriors send David Lee to Celtics for Gerald Wallace
data.text:
LAS VEGAS — David Lee, a former All-Star for the Warriors who accepted a bench role on their NBA championship team, is headed to the Boston Celtics in a trade for Gerald Wallace that was agreed upon Tuesday.

The swap of 32-year-old forwards was a cost-cutting move for the Warriors, who unloaded their highest-paid player in order to save nearly $24 million. Lee was owed $15.5 million in the final year of his contract, and the Warriors softened the blow of the luxury tax bill they are expected to pay next season.

Wallace, who averaged 8.9 minutes in only 32 games last season, will be paid $10.1 million in the last year of his contract and could be waived.

The deal also could allow Lee to play more minutes after his career low in starts came last season.

“(Warriors general manager) Bob Myers worked very hard with me to try and get David to a place he wanted to be,” Mark Bartlestein, Lee’s agent, told TNT’s David Aldridge. “Boston is a great basketball town, great history with that franchise. It’s an up-and-coming team.

“Every player wants to go where they can have a huge impact on a team’s success.”

On Instagram, Lee wrote, “Much Love for the Bay and for the Warriors and I’m truly blessed to have been a part of it.’

Lee, one of the first major free agents to land with the Warriors in recent years, became the first to depart their championship team. In recent days, the Warriors agreed to deals to bring back Draymond Green, Marreese Speights and Leandro Barbosa.

The sign-and-trade deal with the New York Knicks in 2010 brought Lee to the Bay Area with six-year, $80 million contract. In five seasons with the Warriors, he averaged 16.7 points and 9.3 rebounds and went to the All-Star game in 2013. Lee wrote that they were the best five years of his life.

“The journey from a 23 win team to NBA Champs is one I’ll never forget,” Lee wrote. “Thanks to the most loyal fans in basketball for supporting me the entire way!”

The championship season marked a time for Lee to step aside. When he missed time at the start of the season because of a hamstring injury, Green stepped into the lineup and proved to be indispensable.

Lee never publicly complained about losing his spot in the lineup and rotation, drawing praise from coach Steve Kerr for the example that was set. He ultimately played key minutes in the final four games of the NBA Finals.

Knowing his days as a Warrior were likely over, Lee even treated his teammates to a celebratory trip to Las Vegas after the championship was won.

“Wish my big bro @Dlee042 nothing but the best and I appreciate you showing me the way Champ!!!” Green tweeted. “Much love.”

During the summer league team’s first practice, first-round draft pick Kevon Looney was briefly hunched over in discomfort and sidelined because of what he acknowledged was a “little bit” of a hip-related issue. The scrimmage was stopped momentarily, and he missed a play before returning to finish the practice.

Looney had been cleared to participate in the NBA Summer League in Las Vegas and was scheduled to be re-evaluated after playing to see if any medical procedure was needed for the hip injury he originally suffered before his freshman season at UCLA, according to the Warriors.

“Dealing with an injury is always tough,” Warriors summer league head coach Luke Walton said, adding that he was told Looney was cleared to do everything. “He needs to be in better shape.

“I just know from personal experience when you’re dealing with an injury, you can’t do all the training you want to. For whatever reason, his conditioning needs to get better. … You’ve got to be able to run for days. We’ll get him there.”

The skillful 6-foot-9 Looney otherwise impressed Walton, who had the 19-year-old play center on a day when he signed his rookie-scale contract.

For more on the Warriors, see the Inside the Warriors blog at www.ibabuzz.com/warriors. Follow Diamond Leung on Twitter at twitter.com/diamond83.

Lee’s warriors career

July 9, 2010: Warriors acquire 27-year-old David Lee from Knicks in sign-and-trade that sends Kelenna Azubuike, Anthony Randolph, Ronny Turiaf and two draft picks to New York. Lee, coming off an All-Star season, signs an $80 million deal over six years.

Feb, 17, 2013: Lee is first Warrior to play in All-Star game since Latrell Sprewell in 1997.

2014-15: After averaging 18.2 points and 9.3 rebounds in 2013-14, Lee opens 2014-15 with a hamstring injury. When he returns to court, Lee plays behind emerging star Draymond Green.

2015 NBA Finals: After receiving first playing time in a Game 3 loss, Lee helps even series with nine points, five rebounds and three assists in a Game 4 win in Cleveland. Warriors defeat Cavs in six games.
